hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah. The city always changes. Some of us just watch more closely.
I still shoot photos, old-school. Caught some odd ones lately.
The blackout made the streets look different. Worth a frame or two.
Guess we all find our ways to document chaos.
Always a new angle out there. Analog photography—film, not digital.
The referendum chaos put some real stories on the streets.
Snapped a roll during the blackout. Streets felt half empty, half dangerous.
That kind of night, you keep your focus tight. No names, just faces.
Stenograd’s never looked more honest through a lens.
Same city, but my camera tells a different story each week.
I shoot on thirty-five-millimeter film. No edits, no system erasing.
During the AI shutdown, the city dropped its mask. Powerful for photos.
Scored some shots of old ghosts turning up again. That hit hard.
Makes you wonder what we miss when the score’s running.
I trust my negatives more than any official archive.
Truth is, I document Stenograd on film—real film, smuggled rolls.
Shot all night after the referendum crash. Found people, not profiles.
Kids who disappeared from the lists—back in plain view. I got their stories on film.
The city breathes differently when nobody’s scoring us.
I grew up around BCI guys. Photos were my private rebellion.
Those images will outlive these shaky times, if I’m lucky.
The lab I use is off-grid—nothing digital touches my work.
Every story in this city, I hunt with my Smena and a stash of expired film.
Started young—my father worked BCI. Photography kept me honest, kept me human.
When the Halden-AI shut down, I burned through three rolls in two hours.
Snapped people laughing, plotting—kids returning from digital ghosting.
Captured a security chief passing out bread, no uniform, just another neighbor.
Been running a little secret archive, analog only. Blackout nights add pages.
Film’s hard to come by these days. Swapped for bread or old council scripts.
One day, these frames will tell the truth we were never scored for.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still using analog film. No digital trail, that's the point.
Didn’t have much to shoot lately. City’s too quiet.
AI suspension just means people glance around more.
Can’t risk being caught with negatives right now.
Everyone’s unpredictable since the vote fiasco.
Still on the old camera. Film’s hard to find, but safer.
Last week, I only shot empty streets—too many eyes out.
After the AI self-suspended, people get edgy fast.
Developing film gets trickier without clean supplies or trust.
Snapped some scenes after voting chaos, but kept them hidden.
Not sure what’s being watched anymore.
Yeah, still chasing ghosts with my camera.
Night after the AI dropped out, the city changed vibe.
People let their guard down—or got wild. Made for rare photos.
The light felt different. Like nobody cared who was watching.
I shot a protest mural and actual ballot swapping—nobody flinched.
Supply shortages make it harder, but moments like that are worth it.
Hobby feels almost... political lately.
Always. Nothing breathes like chemical film—digital misses half the story.
After AI shutdown, even the city’s noise feels different.
Took some of my best street shots the night voting glitched.
Suddenly, everyone’s faces were real, not posed for compliance.
Ghost score kids started reappearing, messing with slogans and stunts.
Almost felt like honest chaos, like before everything got engineered.
Smuggled film’s running out, but that night was electric.
Camera’s more risk, but it’s how I remember who we are.
You know me—analog is survival. Feels truer than any compliance feed.
First night the AI went dark, I ran out shooting instead of hiding.
Documented more in two hours than a month before the vote.
Kids from the watchlist played for the lens, wild and proud.
Saw ballot swapping by firelight, nobody policing, just raw Stenograd.
It felt dangerous, but strangely free—like just for a second we existed unplugged.
Film’s scarce, had to barter with a tech for a single roll.
I’m storing these negatives like gold. Might be evidence, might be hope.
Honestly, I shoot to prove we’re real when the system tries to paint us out.
